title.narrative: Sugarcane Programme for Southern Africa

description.narrative: The sugarcane sector in Southern Africa is dominated by three large companies: lllovo, Tongaat Hullett and TSB; smallholders are contract farmers with limited, if any, negotiation power. In 2020, the sugarcane sector in Southern Africa was hampered by Covid-19, causing delays in the field work and in the negotiations in Zambia for possible continuation. Digital training materials were developed and WhatsApp groups were established to continue providing training and support to 4,675 farmers. The implementation of good production practices led to yields increase in Malawi (25%) and in South Africa (2%). In Zambia, although farmers experienced an improvement in 2019 of 17%, their productivity in 2020 was affected by severe droughts, which caused a yield drop (-20%). Therefore, we have initiated negotiations with Illovo and CRIDF, to start a revolving fund for small growers in Zambia, that allows them to convert their irrigation systems into water efficient systems such as drip irrigation. We have collaborated with Illovo in South Africa to deliver training to the growers and their contractors on business management and labour relations. This has led to the improvement of the relations between 2,133 growers and their contractors, holding them accountable for the service they are providing. Sugarcane farmers in Malawi, managed to raise funds (68,000 euros) to maintain their association, to influence the policy framework with the government. They have also negotiated a 7,5% sucrose price increase (from USD318 to USD342) with sugar giant Illovo. In Zambia, we assisted the sugarcane farmers to finalize the establishment of the Sugarcane Association of Zambia, where growers and millers agree on the legislation needed for the sector, and through which they advocate for the improvements in the regulatory frameworks.

comment.narrative: Sugarcane Growers Association of MAlawi (SUGAM): helped to develop policy to better promote interests of 4000 outgrowers Kasinthula: helped with debt management for 762 members Phata, Kama and Kasinthula leaders participated in training on gender inclusive policy development and polices have been revised.

title.narrative: Tools, models and incubators developed, tested and available
# tools and models developed and tested that facilitate Service Sector Developme
# tools and models developed and tested that facilitate Service Sector Developme

comment.narrative: Capacity building curriculum for service providers The project is eveloping a curriculum for 10 service providers so that they can be trained on contract management, financial management and improvements in provision of services to the growers.

title.narrative: # tools and models developed and tested that facilitate Service Sector Developme

comment.narrative: Regulatory Framework: Purpose of tool as per montioring framework: improved labour access tools and models improved input access tools and models improved access to credit and/or capital tools and models knowledge tools and improved access to knowledge models marketing and sales tools, and improved access to market models and partnerships tools and models to improve participation of women and youth in decision making in coops, producer groups and service providers Partnership model between Kasinthula Cane Growers and Bank: The project has helped Kasinthula Cane Growers Limited (KCGL) and its 762 members, to engage with their bank in finding a solution to their debt which they had standing since 1997. We successfully managed to restore the working relationship between KCGL and the bank and set up a partnership model for the association. KCGL was assisted to revise their cashflow projections and present new projections to the bank and to negotiate for better conditions to their loan repayment.
